Abraham Lincoln was part of the National Union Party during the 1864 presidential election. The party was formed to accommodate both Democrats and Republicans, with the aim of stressing the national character of the war. Lincoln had initially won the 1860 presidential election as a member of the Republican Party but ran under the National Union Party in 1864 to win the support of War Democrats. The party dropped Vice President Hannibal Hamlin from the ticket in favor of Andrew Johnson, a War Democrat. Lincoln's involvement in the party and his strategic decisions reflect his ability to adapt to the political landscape and form alliances to achieve his goals.
